elements.content: In order to explore novel colorimetric biosensors with high sensibility and selectivity, two new Keggin polyoxometalates (POMs)-based Cu-trz (1,2,4-triazole) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with suitable specific surface areas and multiple active sites were favorably fabricated; then single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) were merged with new POMOFs to construct POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites. Herein, POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites as peroxidase mimics were explored for the first time, and the peroxidase-mimicking activity of the prepared POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites is heavily dependent on the mass ratio of POMOFs and SWNTs, in which the maximum activity is achieved at the mass ratio of 2.5:1 (named PMNT-2). More importantly, PMNT-2 exhibits the lowest limit of detection (0.103 μM) among all reported materials to date and the assumable selectivity toward l-cysteine (l-Cys) detection. With these findings, a convenient, sensitive, and effective “on–off switch” colorimetric platform for l-Cys detection has been successfully developed, providing a promising prospect in the biosensors and clinical diagnosis fields.

elements.content: l-Cysteine (l-Cys), as a semiessential amino acid in biological fluids, plays an important role in living systems, and disordered l-Cys levels can lead to retarded growth of children, hair decolorization, liver and skins damage, and even cancers. Therefore, its detection and quantification is vital in health examination and medical diagnosis. Therefore, diverse technical methods, including fluorescence spectroscopy, electrochemical technique, high-performance liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry, and gas chromatography, have been explored. However, because of their complex procedures and time-consuming nature, accompanied by the need for skilled personnel and complicated instruments, these aforementioned methods hindered practical applications. In contrast, the colorimetric biosensing approach can break through the abovementioned limitations to some extent, because of its easy operation, cheapness, satisfactory sensitivity and selectivity, and so on. Recently, the peroxidase-mimicking catalytic reaction system has been employed as a typical colorimetric biosensor toward l-Cys detection, showing a gratifying prospect in biotechnology.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

 l-Cysteine (l-Cys), as a semiessential amino acid in biological fluids, plays an important role in living systems, and disordered l-Cys levels can lead to retarded growth of children, hair decolorization, liver and skins damage, and even cancers. Therefore, its detection and quantification is vital in health examination and medical diagnosis. Therefore, diverse technical methods, including fluorescence spectroscopy, electrochemical technique, high-performance liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry, and gas chromatography, have been explored. However, because of their complex procedures and time-consuming nature, accompanied by the need for skilled personnel and complicated instruments, these aforementioned methods hindered practical applications. In contrast, the colorimetric biosensing approach can break through the abovementioned limitations to some extent, because of its easy operation, cheapness, satisfactory sensitivity and selectivity, and so on. Recently, the peroxidase-mimicking catalytic reaction system has been employed as a typical colorimetric biosensor toward l-Cys detection, showing a gratifying prospect in biotechnology.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a class of excellent inorganic nanoclusters with tunable acid/base and excellent redox properties, which recently have attracted research interests in colorimetric biosensing. For instance, PW12O40, SiW12O40, and tetranuclear zirconium-substituted POMs showed excellent peroxidase-mimicking activities; namely, POMs can act as catalyst oxidate 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) in the presence of H2O2 through multi-step electron transfer processes to generate a colored substance. Nevertheless, the relatively small surface areas (<10 m2·g–1), poor recovery issues, and environmental contamination hindered their application. Simultaneously, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have become a very interesting study focus owing to their big specific surface areas, regulatable pore shapes, and broad applications in catalysis, sensors, drug delivery, sorption, separation, and so forth. Recently, MOFs as colorimetric biosensors have been also explored, such as porphyrinic Fe­(III)-centralized PCN-222, MIL-53 and MIL-68 based on Fe­(III), and MOF-808 containing Zr–OH­(OH2) groups. Thus, the high-performance colorimetric biosensor might be gained if we can combine the advantages and overcome the shortcomings of POMs and MOFs synchronously, that is, POM-based MOFs (POMOFs). To date, some POMOFs, including Cu6(trz)10(H2O)4[H2SiW12O40] and Na4H2[Cu4(im)14]­[Cu3(H2O)3(BiW9O33)2], have been used as colorimetric biosensors, and the synergistic effect among the components does improve the peroxidase-mimicking activities. It is a pity that the poor conductivity of POMOFs results in relatively lower peroxidase-like activity and higher limit of detection (LOD). Single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), as a new allotropic form of carbon, have been considered to be extremely useful leading candidates to prepare an unprecedented colorimetric biosensor based on POMOFs and SWNTs, because organic molecules in MOFs may enhance the affinity of POMs and substrate SWNTs by non-covalent interactions, including π-π stacking or H-bonding, thus enhancing their peroxidase-mimicking activity. Especially, SWNTs have been traditionally found to be excellent colorimetric biosensors, which guide the promising prospect for the design of SWNT-based biosensors.

Nevertheless, the relatively small surface areas (<10 m2⋅g-1), poor recovery issues, and environmental contamination hindered their application. elements.content: Herein, we present the fabrication of colorimetric biosensor by integrating POMs, MOFs, and SWNTs for the first time. In the work, 1,2,4-triazole (trz) was selected as organic molecule because of its vital role in affinity enhancement and charge transfer; thus, two new [PW12O40]3–-based Cu-trz MOFs were successfully fabricated through pH transformation, formulated as [Cu18(trz)12Cl3(H2O)2]­[PW12O40] (Cu18PW12) and [CuI 2CuII 4(trz)8Cl2]­[PW12O40] (Cu6PW12). Then, the POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites (PMNTs) were prepared by employing a simple sonication-driven periodic functionalization strategy. The results of the peroxidase-mimicking catalytic activity evaluation of PMNTs indicate that the integration of SWNTs and POMOFs greatly enhanced the peroxidase-mimicking activity because of the short interactions between POMOFs and SWNTs and the higher affinity of PMNTs with substrates. Most importantly, a simple, highly sensitive and selective “on–off switch” colorimetric approach for l-Cys detection has been developed. Note that the PMNT nanocomposite exhibits the best performance among all reported materials as l-Cys colorimetric biosensors to date ().

elements.content: All reagents purchased commercially were used without purification, and deionized water was used in the experiments. The methods of material characterization are provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents purchased commercially were used without purification, and deionized water was used in the experiments. The methods of material characterization are provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content:
The detailed synthesis experiment of materials is provided in the Supporting Information.

Fabrication of Cu<sub>18</sub>PW<sub>12</sub>NC/SWNTs

Purified SWNTs (20 mg) were dispersed in 15 mL methanol under 60 kHz ultrasonication for 1 h. Then, 40 mg Cu18PW12NC in 2 mL acetonitrile was transferred to the above SWNT–methanol solution, and the resulting mixture was sonicated for another 1 h. Then, the composite was isolated by centrifugation and rinsed using dry methanol and dried at 40 °C overnight. Three experiments were carried out under the different mass ratios of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs (2:1, 2.5:1, and 3:1), and the corresponding three nanocomposites were obtained and abbreviated as PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of POMOFs and Nano-POMOFs

The detailed synthesis experiment of materials is provided in the Supporting Information.

Fabrication of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs

Purified SWNTs (20 mg) were dispersed in 15 mL methanol under 60 kHz ultrasonication for 1 h. Then, 40 mg Cu18PW12NC in 2 mL acetonitrile was transferred to the above SWNT-methanol solution, and the resulting mixture was sonicated for another 1 h. Then, the composite was isolated by centrifugation and rinsed using dry methanol and dried at 40 °C overnight. Three experiments were carried out under the different mass ratios of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs (2:1, 2.5:1, and 3:1), and the corresponding three nanocomposites were obtained and abbreviated as PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3, respectively.

elements.content: Typically, TMB (150 μM), H2O2 (100 μM), and catalyst (0.6 mg/mL) were added into the acetate buffer solution (pH 3.5) in turn, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 40 °C, and then filtered using a syringe filter immediately. The UV absorbance of the filtrates at 661 nm was measured to evaluate the oxTMB content. In addition, the influence of pH (2.5–6.0) and temperature (25–55 °C) on the activity were also investigated in a similar assay.
elements.clean_text:
Peroxidase-like Activity Evaluation of As-Prepared Samples

Typically, TMB (150 μM), H2O2 (100 μM), and catalyst (0.6 mg/mL) were added into the acetate buffer solution (pH 3.5) in turn, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 40 °C, and then filtered using a syringe filter immediately. The UV absorbance of the filtrates at 661 nm was measured to evaluate the oxTMB content. In addition, the influence of pH (2.5-6.0) and temperature (25-55 °C) on the activity were also investigated in a similar assay.

elements.content: The catalytic activity of PMNT-2 was evaluated using the Michaelis–Menten model, and the apparent steady-state kinetic parameters were determined under optimal conditions by changing the concentrations of TMB (0.04; 0.08; 0.12 mM) with the constant concentration of H2O2 (0.1 mM). Conversely, the concentrations of H2O2 (0.03; 0.06; 0.1 mM) was changed with the constant concentration of TMB (0.04 mM).
elements.clean_text:
Steady-State Kinetics Assay

The catalytic activity of PMNT-2 was evaluated using the Michaelis-Menten model, and the apparent steady-state kinetic parameters were determined under optimal conditions by changing the concentrations of TMB (0.04; 0.08; 0.12 mM) with the constant concentration of H2O2 (0.1 mM). Conversely, the concentrations of H2O2 (0.03; 0.06; 0.1 mM) was changed with the constant concentration of TMB (0.04 mM).

elements.content: For H2O2 detection, the standard curve of H2O2 was established at 40 °C for 5 min. The colorimetric detection assay of l-Cys was also carried out; more specifically, TMB (150 μM), H2O2 (100 μM), catalyst (0.6 mg/mL), and a certain amount of l-Cys were added into the acetate buffer solution (pH 3.5) in turn; then the mixture solutions were shaken and equilibrated for 60 s and filtered using a syringe filter immediately. The oxTMB content was tested through UV spectra at 661 nm.
elements.clean_text:
H2O2 and l-Cys Detection Assay

For H2O2 detection, the standard curve of H2O2 was established at 40 °C for 5 min. The colorimetric detection assay of l-Cys was also carried out; more specifically, TMB (150 μM), H2O2 (100 μM), catalyst (0.6 mg/mL), and a certain amount of l-Cys were added into the acetate buffer solution (pH 3.5) in turn; then the mixture solutions were shaken and equilibrated for 60 s and filtered using a syringe filter immediately. The oxTMB content was tested through UV spectra at 661 nm.

elements.content: Several potential interfering solutions coexisting in real samples, including glutamic acid (Glu), alanine (Ala), lysine (Lys), glycine (Gly), tyrosine (Tyr), Na+, Ca2+, K+, Mg2+, Cl–, and NO3 –, were prepared (200 μM). For l-Cys determination in real samples, the urine and serum samples were treated by centrifugation (12 000 rpm, 30 min) first to obtain the supernatants for the next-step measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Selectivity Evaluation in l-Cys Detection

Several potential interfering solutions coexisting in real samples, including glutamic acid (Glu), alanine (Ala), lysine (Lys), glycine (Gly), tyrosine (Tyr), Na+, Ca2+, K+, Mg2+, Cl-, and NO3 -, were prepared (200 μM). For l-Cys determination in real samples, the urine and serum samples were treated by centrifugation (12000 rpm, 30 min) first to obtain the supernatants for the next-step measurement.

elements.content: Cu18PW12 and Cu6PW12 samples were synthesized under similar conditions except for pH value. Structural analysis reveals that Cu18PW12 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and displays a glamorous 2D-in-3D organic–inorganic hybrid framework, whereas Cu6PW12 crystallizes in triclinic P1̅ space group and exhibits a POM-pillared 3D framework. Cu18PW12 consists of a half [PW12O40]3– (hereafter PW12), six trz ligands, ten Cu ions, two Cl anions, and one lattice water molecule (Figure S2a). Cu6PW12 is composed of one PW12 polyoxoanion, eight trz ligands, six Cu ions, and two Cl ions (Figure S4a). Bond-valence sum calculations (Tables S2 and S3) suggest that all W atoms are in full oxidation states in both compounds, and all Cu atoms are in the +I state in Cu18PW12, whereas one Cu atom is in the +I state in Cu6PW12. The coordination states of Cu ions and PW12 are illustrated in Figures S2 and S4. Moreover, each trz ligand fully adopts the μ1,2,4-coordination mode in Cu18PW12 (Figure S2d), whereas trz ligands in Cu6PW12 adopt μ1,2,4- and μ1,2-coordinated modes (Figure S4c). The bond lengths range from 2.403 to 2.731 Å for Cu–O and 1.842–2.012 Å for Cu–N in Cu18PW12, and 2.382–2.604 Å for Cu–O and 1.873–2.032 Å for Cu–N in Cu6PW12.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of Cu18PW12 and Cu6PW12 

Cu18PW12 and Cu6PW12 samples were synthesized under similar conditions except for pH value. Structural analysis reveals that Cu18PW12 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and displays a glamorous 2D-in-3D organic-inorganic hybrid framework, whereas Cu6PW12 crystallizes in triclinic P1̅ space group and exhibits a POM-pillared 3D framework. Cu18PW12 consists of a half [PW12O40]3- (hereafter PW12), six trz ligands, ten Cu ions, two Cl anions, and one lattice water molecule (Figure S2a). Cu6PW12 is composed of one PW12 polyoxoanion, eight trz ligands, six Cu ions, and two Cl ions (Figure S4a). Bond-valence sum calculations (Tables S2 and S3) suggest that all W atoms are in full oxidation states in both compounds, and all Cu atoms are in the +I state in Cu18PW12, whereas one Cu atom is in the +I state in Cu6PW12. The coordination states of Cu ions and PW12 are illustrated in Figures S2 and S4. Moreover, each trz ligand fully adopts the μ1,2,4-coordination mode in Cu18PW12 (Figure S2d), whereas trz ligands in Cu6PW12 adopt μ1,2,4- and μ1,2-coordinated modes (Figure S4c). The bond lengths range from 2.403 to 2.731 Å for Cu-O and 1.842-2.012 Å for Cu-N in Cu18PW12, and 2.382-2.604 Å for Cu-O and 1.873-2.032 Å for Cu-N in Cu6PW12.

elements.content: On the one hand, two types of [Cu4(trz)4Cl] subunits with a “pyrazole-like” bridging mode exist in Cu18PW12 (denoted as subunit A and subunit B in Figure S3a). Adjacent subunits A are fixed by Cu7 and Cu9 ions to give the metal–organic layer A; meanwhile, the adjacent subunits B are connected by Cu6 ions to form the metal–organic layer B ( and S3b). On the other hand, PW12 polyoxoanions are fused together through Cu9 and Cu6 ions, giving birth to the inorganic layer (Figure S3c). Moreover, adjacent inorganic layers are further connected by Cu6 ions, generating the 3D inorganic framework comprising 1D channels along the crystallographic a-, b-, and c-axes (). As a consequence, the metal–organic layers are inserted into 3D inorganic frameworks in an A–B–A–A–B–A parallel staggering mode via Cu–O bonds, leading to the formation of a well closed 2D-in-3D hybrid framework ( and S3d).
elements.clean_text: On the one hand, two types of [Cu4(trz)4Cl] subunits with a "pyrazole-like" bridging mode exist in Cu18PW12 (denoted as subunit A and subunit B in Figure S3a). Adjacent subunits A are fixed by Cu7 and Cu9 ions to give the metal-organic layer A; meanwhile, the adjacent subunits B are connected by Cu6 ions to form the metal-organic layer B ( and S3b). On the other hand, PW12 polyoxoanions are fused together through Cu9 and Cu6 ions, giving birth to the inorganic layer (Figure S3c). Moreover, adjacent inorganic layers are further connected by Cu6 ions, generating the 3D inorganic framework comprising 1D channels along the crystallographic a-, b-, and c-axes (). As a consequence, the metal-organic layers are inserted into 3D inorganic frameworks in an A-B-A-A-B-A parallel staggering mode via Cu-O bonds, leading to the formation of a well closed 2D-in-3D hybrid framework ( and S3d).

elements.content: Compared with Cu18PW12, two types of Cu-trz motifs can be also extracted in Cu6PW12 (denoted by subunit* A and subunit* B). Then, these subunits* are linked by sharing Cu2 ions, resembling an infinite 1D chain (Figure S5a). The adjacent chains interconnect with Cu1 ions to form a 2D layer (). As we can see, these layers are further stacked parallel through the interactions between PW12 polyoxoanions and Cu centers to fabricate a 3D POM-pillared layer framework (). It is noticeable that two kinds of channels intersect with each other in Cu6PW12 with the dimension of ca. 13.486 × 6.500 Å2 and ca. 11.245 × 7.975 Å2 along a- and b-axes, respectively (Figure S5b,c).

elements.content: Applying topological analysis, Cu18PW12 can be reduced to a (2,4,8)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (44·62)­(46)2(412·612·84)­(88), in which Cu7 acts as two-connected nodes; subunit-A, subunit-B, Cu6, and Cu9 as four-connected nodes; and the PW12 polyoxoanions as eight-connected nodes (Figure S3e). The framework of Cu6PW12 can be reduced to a (2,3,4,6)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (3·8·9)2(32·102·112)­(32·84·94·102·112·12)­(84·10·12)­(8)2, in which Cu1 acts as two-connected nodes, Cu2 as three-connected nodes, PW12 polyoxoanions and subunit* A as four-connected nodes, and subunit* B as six-connected nodes (Figure S5d).
elements.clean_text: Applying topological analysis, Cu18PW12 can be reduced to a (2,4,8)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (44⋅62)(46)2(412⋅612⋅84)(88), in which Cu7 acts as two-connected nodes; subunit-A, subunit-B, Cu6, and Cu9 as four-connected nodes; and the PW12 polyoxoanions as eight-connected nodes (Figure S3e). The framework of Cu6PW12 can be reduced to a (2,3,4,6)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (3⋅8⋅9)2(32⋅102⋅112)(32⋅84⋅94⋅102⋅112⋅12)(84⋅10⋅12)(8)2, in which Cu1 acts as two-connected nodes, Cu2 as three-connected nodes, PW12 polyoxoanions and subunit* A as four-connected nodes, and subunit* B as six-connected nodes (Figure S5d).

elements.content: The structures of as-prepared Cu18PW12, Cu6PW12, Cu18PW12NC, Cu6PW12NC, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 are characterized by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) (a and S6). Cu18PW12NC, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 exhibit similar diffraction patterns with Cu18PW12, confirming good phase purities and crystallinities. Note that the peaks of SWNTs are invisible, maybe because of the small amount of SWNTs. Their Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra are shown in Figures S7 and S8. The characteristic bands at ca. 1060, 962, and 800 cm–1 are ascribed to the P–O, Wt–O, and Wb–O–Wb stretching vibrations. In PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3, the peaks of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs show slight movements, indicating the effective hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs (Scheme S1). Moreover, the Raman spectra of PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 (λex = 633 nm) present characteristic bands at 1326 (D band), 1586 (G band), and 2628 cm–1 (D* band), confirming the presence of SWNTs (b). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Cu18PW12NC and Cu6PW12NC show that both possess uniform shapes and average sizes at ca. 100 nm (Figures S9 and S10). SEM images of PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 are provided, and the SEM image of pristine SWNTs is also provided as control (c and S9). It can be seen that the SWNT bundles loosened upon treatment with Cu18PW12NC, indicating the improved dispersion of SWNTs in the nanocomposite; meanwhile, the intrinsic structure of Cu18PW12NC is well retained. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of SWNTs, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 were provided (d and S11), and the results indicate that a large number of SWNTs are homogeneously located around Cu18PW12NC, and the content of SWNTs is decreased with the increasing mass ratios of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs from 2:1 to 3:1. The uniformity of PMNT-2 is also verified by elemental mapping, and the equidistribution of C, Cu, N, O, P, W, and Cl (e) is consistent with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, FT-IR, Raman, SEM, TEM, and EDX Analyses

The structures of as-prepared Cu18PW12, Cu6PW12, Cu18PW12NC, Cu6PW12NC, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 are characterized by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) (a and S6). Cu18PW12NC, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 exhibit similar diffraction patterns with Cu18PW12, confirming good phase purities and crystallinities. Note that the peaks of SWNTs are invisible, maybe because of the small amount of SWNTs. Their Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra are shown in Figures S7 and S8. The characteristic bands at ca. 1060, 962, and 800 cm-1 are ascribed to the P-O, Wt-O, and Wb-O-Wb stretching vibrations. In PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3, the peaks of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs show slight movements, indicating the effective hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs (Scheme S1). Moreover, the Raman spectra of PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 (λex = 633 nm) present characteristic bands at 1326 (D band), 1586 (G band), and 2628 cm-1 (D* band), confirming the presence of SWNTs (b). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Cu18PW12NC and Cu6PW12NC show that both possess uniform shapes and average sizes at ca. 100 nm (Figures S9 and S10). SEM images of PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 are provided, and the SEM image of pristine SWNTs is also provided as control (c and S9). It can be seen that the SWNT bundles loosened upon treatment with Cu18PW12NC, indicating the improved dispersion of SWNTs in the nanocomposite; meanwhile, the intrinsic structure of Cu18PW12NC is well retained. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of SWNTs, PMNT-1, PMNT-2, and PMNT-3 were provided (d and S11), and the results indicate that a large number of SWNTs are homogeneously located around Cu18PW12NC, and the content of SWNTs is decreased with the increasing mass ratios of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs from 2:1 to 3:1. The uniformity of PMNT-2 is also verified by elemental mapping, and the equidistribution of C, Cu, N, O, P, W, and Cl (e) is consistent with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry (Figure S12).

elements.content: A typical method for the catalytic oxidation of TMB is adopted to explore the peroxidase-mimicking activities of as-synthesized samples. As shown in a, TMB can be oxidized to produce green color (λ = 661 nm) under the existence of PMNT-1 as the catalyst, demonstrating the peroxidase-mimicking property of PMNT-1. However, the solution color does not change in the absence of PMNT-1, or H2O2, or TMB. The results indicate that PMNT-1 has high peroxidase-mimicking activities when H2O2 serves as oxidant. In addition, the peroxidase-mimicking properties of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs were also conducted and exhibited lower catalytic performances (b, S13, and S14), indicating that the synergetic effect between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs can improve the peroxidase-mimicking performance of nanocomposites. More specifically, the non-covalent interactions between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs, including H-bonding or π–π stacking, can generate a smart microenvironment for the access of H2O2 and TMB to drive the movement of TMB and H2O2 toward PMNT-1. Moreover, the loose packing of SWNTs provides a rational pathway for H2O2 moving toward active centers. As a consequence, the stronger affinity of PMNTs with H2O2 and TMB can be guaranteed and is beneficial in enhancing the peroxidase-mimicking activity. It should also be mentioned that the introduction of SWNTs may improve the biocompatibility of PMNT-1 for bioapplications. Considering that Cu6PW12NC shows poor peroxidase-mimicking activity than Cu18PW12NC (b and S13), Cu18PW12NC was selected to construct POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites for subsequent activity analysis.

Peroxidase-like Catalytic Activity and Optimal Reaction Conditions

A typical method for the catalytic oxidation of TMB is adopted to explore the peroxidase-mimicking activities of as-synthesized samples. As shown in a, TMB can be oxidized to produce green color (λ = 661 nm) under the existence of PMNT-1 as the catalyst, demonstrating the peroxidase-mimicking property of PMNT-1. However, the solution color does not change in the absence of PMNT-1, or H2O2, or TMB. The results indicate that PMNT-1 has high peroxidase-mimicking activities when H2O2 serves as oxidant. In addition, the peroxidase-mimicking properties of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs were also conducted and exhibited lower catalytic performances (b, S13, and S14), indicating that the synergetic effect between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs can improve the peroxidase-mimicking performance of nanocomposites. More specifically, the non-covalent interactions between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs, including H-bonding or π-π stacking, can generate a smart microenvironment for the access of H2O2 and TMB to drive the movement of TMB and H2O2 toward PMNT-1. Moreover, the loose packing of SWNTs provides a rational pathway for H2O2 moving toward active centers. As a consequence, the stronger affinity of PMNTs with H2O2 and TMB can be guaranteed and is beneficial in enhancing the peroxidase-mimicking activity. It should also be mentioned that the introduction of SWNTs may improve the biocompatibility of PMNT-1 for bioapplications. Considering that Cu6PW12NC shows poor peroxidase-mimicking activity than Cu18PW12NC (b and S13), Cu18PW12NC was selected to construct POMOF/SWNT nanocomposites for subsequent activity analysis.

elements.content: Similar to most reported peroxidase mimics, the influences of pH, temperature, and catalyst dosage on peroxidase-like catalytic activities of PMNT-1 were also explored (c and S15). The response curves show the highest peroxidase-mimicking activities at pH 3.5, 45 °C, and 0.6 mg/mL catalyst. Considering that PMNT-1 also possesses excellent catalytic activity at 40 °C, and higher temperature can cause fast decomposition of H2O2, 40 °C was adopted as the first-rank reaction temperature to conduct the subsequent peroxidase-mimicking activity. In addition, we found that the peroxidase-mimicking activities of PMNTs are heavily dependent on the mass ratios of Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs because of the synergistic effect with different levels. As shown in d and S16, PMNT-2 (Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs = 2.5:1) exhibits the highest peroxidase-mimicking catalytic activity among three PMNTs. Therefore, PMNT-2 was selected for the subsequent peroxidase-mimicking activity evaluation.

elements.content: To further illustrate the synergetic effect of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs in PMNT nanocomposites, PMNTs­(M) [PMNT­(M)-1, PMNT­(M)-2, and PMNT­(M)-3] were adopted as contrasts to study the peroxidase-mimicking activity (Figure S17). The results show that their peroxidase-mimicking activities are considerably less than those of PMNT nanocomposites, which further indicates that the synergetic effect between Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs is vital to the peroxidase-mimicking activity advancement.

elements.content: For the purpose of studying the peroxidase-mimicking catalytic efficiency of PMNT-2, a steady-state kinetic experiment was performed by changing one substrate concentration with the constant concentration of other substrate. As shown in Figure S18a,b, the data were fitted to the Michaelis–Menten equation, in which Michaelis constant K m represents the affinity of the enzyme toward the substrate and the value is equivalent to the substrate concentration when the reaction rate is half of V max. As we known that K m value is smaller, the affinity between the enzyme (PMNT-2) and the substrate (H2O2 and TMB) is stronger. Herein, the K m values of the PMNT-2 as catalyst toward H2O2 and TMB are 0.206 and 0.021 mM, respectively, which is lower than reported materials, and the V max value is higher than most reported materials (). The results demonstrate that PMNT-2 possesses higher affinity with TMB and H2O2 and superior catalytic efficiency than that of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs (Figures S19 and S20), which further testify our speculation.
elements.clean_text:
Steady-State Kinetics and Fundamental Catalytic Mechanism Assays of PMNT-2 

For the purpose of studying the peroxidase-mimicking catalytic efficiency of PMNT-2, a steady-state kinetic experiment was performed by changing one substrate concentration with the constant concentration of other substrate. As shown in Figure S18a,b, the data were fitted to the Michaelis-Menten equation, in which Michaelis constant K m represents the affinity of the enzyme toward the substrate and the value is equivalent to the substrate concentration when the reaction rate is half of V max. As we known that K m value is smaller, the affinity between the enzyme (PMNT-2) and the substrate (H2O2 and TMB) is stronger. Herein, the K m values of the PMNT-2 as catalyst toward H2O2 and TMB are 0.206 and 0.021 mM, respectively, which is lower than reported materials, and the V max value is higher than most reported materials (). The results demonstrate that PMNT-2 possesses higher affinity with TMB and H2O2 and superior catalytic efficiency than that of Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs (Figures S19 and S20), which further testify our speculation.

The double reciprocal plots of the initial velocity against one substrate concentration were obtained over a range of the second substrate concentrations shown in Figure S18c,d. The almost parallel lines indicate that the catalytic reaction follows the ping-pong mechanism. In addition, the nature of TMB catalytic reaction may originate from the formation of the hydroxyl radical (•OH). Thus, the probing technique of the terephthalic acid (TA) photoluminescence was employed to determine •OH formation (Scheme S2). As expected, the fluorescence of TA was switched on upon the introduction of H2O2 and PMNT-2, and the fluorescence intensity of the PMNT-2 solution was above 10 times higher than that of the same solution except for no PMNT-2. The fact indicates that PMNT-2 indeed can activate H2O2 to produce •OH (Figure S21). As a comparison, the fluorescence intensities of the solutions containing Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs are lower than that of PMNT-2, suggesting that less •OH is generated, which is coincident with the peroxidase-mimicking activities of these three systems.

The almost parallel lines indicate that the catalytic reaction follows the ping-pong mechanism. In addition, the nature of TMB catalytic reaction may originate from the formation of the hydroxyl radical (⋅OH). Thus, the probing technique of the terephthalic acid (TA) photoluminescence was employed to determine ⋅OH formation (Scheme S2). As expected, the fluorescence of TA was switched on upon the introduction of H2O2 and PMNT-2, and the fluorescence intensity of the PMNT-2 solution was above 10 times higher than that of the same solution except for no PMNT-2. The fact indicates that PMNT-2 indeed can activate H2O2 to produce ⋅OH (Figure S21). As a comparison, the fluorescence intensities of the solutions containing Cu18PW12NC and SWNTs are lower than that of PMNT-2, suggesting that less ⋅OH is generated, which is coincident with the peroxidase-mimicking activities of these three systems.

elements.content: Given that the peroxidase-mimicking activities of PMNT-2 greatly rely on H2O2 concentration, a convenient “turn on” approach could be used for the quantitative evaluation of H2O2 (Scheme S3). The absorption changes at 661 nm by varying H2O2 concentrations were measured under the first-rank conditions (40 °C, pH 3.5) shown in Figure S22a. It is clear that the reaction rate rises with the H2O2 concentration increasing in the range of 1–1000 μM. The typical concentration-response curves are presented in Figure S22b,c, indicating a wide linear relationship of absorbance value versus H2O2 concentrations between 1 and 100 μM (R 2 = 0.9943). Furthermore, LOD can be calculated as 0.092 μM (LOD = K·S 0/S). The LOD is lower than that of MOF-808 (4.5 μM), MIL-68 (0.256 μM), and FF@PW12@GO (0.11 μM), implying the superiority for H2O2 colorimetric sensing. Synchronously, the color variation could be observed easily, which provides a facile and simple approach for H2O2 detection with the naked eye even under lower H2O2 concentration (Figure S22d).
elements.clean_text:
Detection of H2O2 

Given that the peroxidase-mimicking activities of PMNT-2 greatly rely on H2O2 concentration, a convenient "turn on" approach could be used for the quantitative evaluation of H2O2 (Scheme S3). The absorption changes at 661 nm by varying H2O2 concentrations were measured under the first-rank conditions (40 °C, pH 3.5) shown in Figure S22a. It is clear that the reaction rate rises with the H2O2 concentration increasing in the range of 1-1000 μM. The typical concentration-response curves are presented in Figure S22b,c, indicating a wide linear relationship of absorbance value versus H2O2 concentrations between 1 and 100 μM (R 2 = 0.9943). Furthermore, LOD can be calculated as 0.092 μM (LOD = K⋅S 0/S). The LOD is lower than that of MOF-808 (4.5 μM), MIL-68 (0.256 μM), and FF@PW12@GO (0.11 μM), implying the superiority for H2O2 colorimetric sensing. Synchronously, the color variation could be observed easily, which provides a facile and simple approach for H2O2 detection with the naked eye even under lower H2O2 concentration (Figure S22d).

elements.content: As described in the introduction, l-Cys plays an important role in many physiological processes, so the exploration of more sensitive detecting and quantifying methods of l-Cys attaches great interest, although numerous detection approaches have been reported over the past decades. Because l-Cys can reduce oxTMB to TMB, resulting in the fading of the green color, an efficient and simple “on–off switch” colorimetric assay is established to detect l-Cys (Scheme S3). More specifically, the absorbance intensity reduces with l-Cys concentration increasing in the TMB oxidation system catalyzed by PMNT-2 (a,c), suggesting that l-Cys can inhibit the production of oxTMB molecules. Moreover, the dose-response curves about the decreased absorption value (ΔA) versus l-Cys concentrations after the 5 min reaction are shown in b, suggesting that the corresponding linear calibration plot ranges from 1 to 80 μM (R 2 = 0.9963), and the LOD is about 0.103 μM, which is superior than LaMnO3+δ nanofibers (0.1098 μM) and FeCo-CNFs (0.15 μM). Note that the LOD value is the best among those materials reported as l-Cys biosensors to date (Table S4). Furthermore, to further confirm the reliability of our proposed colorimetric sensor, the detection of l-Cys in human urine and serum samples was also performed, and the results indicate that the recoveries of samples are 96.4–102.9% for human urine samples and 98.9–101.7% for human serum samples (Table S5), demonstrating that the developed approach for l-Cys determination is feasible and reliable.
elements.clean_text:
Detection and Selectivity Assay of l-Cys

As described in the introduction, l-Cys plays an important role in many physiological processes, so the exploration of more sensitive detecting and quantifying methods of l-Cys attaches great interest, although numerous detection approaches have been reported over the past decades. Because l-Cys can reduce oxTMB to TMB, resulting in the fading of the green color, an efficient and simple "on-off switch" colorimetric assay is established to detect l-Cys (Scheme S3). More specifically, the absorbance intensity reduces with l-Cys concentration increasing in the TMB oxidation system catalyzed by PMNT-2 (a,c), suggesting that l-Cys can inhibit the production of oxTMB molecules. Moreover, the dose-response curves about the decreased absorption value (ΔA) versus l-Cys concentrations after the 5 min reaction are shown in b, suggesting that the corresponding linear calibration plot ranges from 1 to 80 μM (R 2 = 0.9963), and the LOD is about 0.103 μM, which is superior than LaMnO3+δ nanofibers (0.1098 μM) and FeCo-CNFs (0.15 μM). Note that the LOD value is the best among those materials reported as l-Cys biosensors to date (Table S4). Furthermore, to further confirm the reliability of our proposed colorimetric sensor, the detection of l-Cys in human urine and serum samples was also performed, and the results indicate that the recoveries of samples are 96.4-102.9% for human urine samples and 98.9-101.7% for human serum samples (Table S5), demonstrating that the developed approach for l-Cys determination is feasible and reliable.

elements.content: Considering that other amino acids and ions in human body may cause interference during the l-Cys detection process, here, glutamic acid (Glu), alanine (Ala), lysine (Lys), glycine (Gly), tyrosine (Tyr), Na+, Ca2+, K+, Mg2+, Cl–, and NO3 – ions were selected to assess their inhibitory effects. As shown in d, the color and absorption intensity at 661 nm almost remain unchanged when these interferential substances as inhibitors exist in the reaction system. However, the reaction system with l-Cys as inhibitor converted to colorless, and an obvious absorption intensity quenching at 661 nm could be observed. This result reveals that PMNT-2 possesses excellent selectivity toward l-Cys detection, which is comparable with LaMnO3+δ nanofibers.

As shown in d, the color and absorption intensity at 661 nm almost remain unchanged when these interferential substances as inhibitors exist in the reaction system. However, the reaction system with l-Cys as inhibitor converted to colorless, and an obvious absorption intensity quenching at 661 nm could be observed. elements.content: On the basis of theoretical and experiment results, we elaborate the l-Cys colorimetric biosensing processes on PMNT-2, and the possible mechanism is summarized in . As proposed in the mechanism, during the colorimetric biosensing process, H2O2 was adsorbed onto the surface of PMNT-2 first, and PW12 polyanions donate electrons initially and transfer them to the metal centers through trz ligands and SWNTs. Then, adsorbed H2O2 was activated by metal centers through the breaking up of O–O bond coupling with the proton–electron transfer, producing double-active •OH stabilized by PMNT-2. Subsequently, TMB molecules were adsorbed on the surface of PMNT-2, donating lone-pair electrons of the amino groups and reacting with desorbed •OH through electron transfer to complete the catalytic oxidation of TMB and the corresponding color change from colorless to green, which is similar to other reported results. When l-Cys is added into the abovementioned system as an inhibitor, oxTMB converts to TMB and l-Cys converts to l-Cystine with disulfide bond simultaneously, leading to the fading of green color.
elements.clean_text:
Overall Mechanism of l-Cys Colorimetric Biosensing on PMNT-2 

On the basis of theoretical and experiment results, we elaborate the l-Cys colorimetric biosensing processes on PMNT-2, and the possible mechanism is summarized in . As proposed in the mechanism, during the colorimetric biosensing process, H2O2 was adsorbed onto the surface of PMNT-2 first, and PW12 polyanions donate electrons initially and transfer them to the metal centers through trz ligands and SWNTs. Then, adsorbed H2O2 was activated by metal centers through the breaking up of O-O bond coupling with the proton-electron transfer, producing double-active ⋅OH stabilized by PMNT-2. Subsequently, TMB molecules were adsorbed on the surface of PMNT-2, donating lone-pair electrons of the amino groups and reacting with desorbed ⋅OH through electron transfer to complete the catalytic oxidation of TMB and the corresponding color change from colorless to green, which is similar to other reported results. When l-Cys is added into the abovementioned system as an inhibitor, oxTMB converts to TMB and l-Cys converts to l-Cystine with disulfide bond simultaneously, leading to the fading of green color.

elements.content: Proposed mechanistic scheme for the l-Cys colorimetric biosensing on PMNT-2 (POMs serve as electron-donating groups, trz ligands and SWNTs as electron transferring groups, and Cu ions as electron collecting groups).
elements.clean_text: 5  Proposed mechanistic scheme for the l-Cys colorimetric biosensing on PMNT-2 (POMs serve as electron-donating groups, trz ligands and SWNTs as electron transferring groups, and Cu ions as electron collecting groups).

elements.content: The PXRD patterns and IR spectra of Cu18PW12NC and PMNT-2 have exactly similar peak position before and after peroxidase-mimicking activity evaluation (Figures S23 and S24), which confirms the ultrahigh stability of Cu18PW12NC and PMNT-2. Moreover, the recycled experiment of PMNT-2 was performed (Figure S25), and the result shows that PMNT-2 exhibits no significant activity decrease after five runs under same conditions, which manifests that PMNT-2 as a peroxidase-mimicking catalyst possesses excellent reproducibility. Furthermore, we tested the usage stability of PMNT-2 as peroxidase mimics. It is found that PMNT-2 still retains above 95% initial activity after immersion in an aqueous solution for 10 days, demonstrating its eminent stability, which is much better than that of natural enzymes reported previously (Figure S26).
elements.clean_text:
Stability and Reproducibility Evaluation of PMNT-2 

The PXRD patterns and IR spectra of Cu18PW12NC and PMNT-2 have exactly similar peak position before and after peroxidase-mimicking activity evaluation (Figures S23 and S24), which confirms the ultrahigh stability of Cu18PW12NC and PMNT-2. Moreover, the recycled experiment of PMNT-2 was performed (Figure S25), and the result shows that PMNT-2 exhibits no significant activity decrease after five runs under same conditions, which manifests that PMNT-2 as a peroxidase-mimicking catalyst possesses excellent reproducibility. Furthermore, we tested the usage stability of PMNT-2 as peroxidase mimics. It is found that PMNT-2 still retains above 95% initial activity after immersion in an aqueous solution for 10 days, demonstrating its eminent stability, which is much better than that of natural enzymes reported previously (Figure S26).

elements.content: In summary, owing to the effective composition, appropriate surface areas, rich active sites, and synergetic effect of components, PMNT-2 nanocomposite (Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs = 2.5:1) as a novel enzyme mimic exhibits superior peroxidase-mimicking catalytic activity. Moreover, a convenient and effective “on–off switch” colorimetric platform based on PMNT-2 has been successfully developed for l-Cys detection with the lowest LOD among all reported peroxidase mimics, and the crucial selectivity can also be assured under the interferences of other common amino acids and ions. This work indeed provides an effective, simple, and low-cost strategy for the fabrication of high-performance nanomaterial as peroxidase mimics and possesses the promising potential applications to extend the diversity of the peroxidase mimics family in the biosensors and clinical diagnosis fields.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, owing to the effective composition, appropriate surface areas, rich active sites, and synergetic effect of components, PMNT-2 nanocomposite (Cu18PW12NC/SWNTs = 2.5:1) as a novel enzyme mimic exhibits superior peroxidase-mimicking catalytic activity. Moreover, a convenient and effective "on-off switch" colorimetric platform based on PMNT-2 has been successfully developed for l-Cys detection with the lowest LOD among all reported peroxidase mimics, and the crucial selectivity can also be assured under the interferences of other common amino acids and ions. This work indeed provides an effective, simple, and low-cost strategy for the fabrication of high-performance nanomaterial as peroxidase mimics and possesses the promising potential applications to extend the diversity of the peroxidase mimics family in the biosensors and clinical diagnosis fields.
